segments.text: Anything like that, if somebody wants you to do it, you ought to be willing to do it a little.
And so I told them I'd take it for one term.
Well, at the end of one term, I had turned it over, but I turned it over to go into World War II.
Because, as you see in there, I was a busy man between two wars.
What did you do during the Second World War?
Inspected kitchens.
I went to, I'd gone to Fort Sill, First World War.
They had sent a lot of people out of the, I was in the Mississippi New Regiment.
It was regiment, New Artillery Regiment from Louisiana and then from Arkansas.
Most of it went there, had no military experience,
and none whatsoever in artillery.

They were, it was a regiment in all three states where the governor said to a friend, you've got a, you're a lieutenant colonel over here in this infantry outfit, go over here, I'll make you a colonel.
But he was an infantryman.
Same thing happened in Arkansas that did in Mississippi and Louisiana.
They didn't have any, they didn't have any artillerymen.
They had people who were foot soldiers that had had any military training, and they didn't want to learn anything else.
After we were federalized, we met at Clinton, and we stayed over there a few weeks, where we drilled, and just in infantry stuff, but I had some artillery books I was studying.
And then they got us over to Jackson where they assembled this Mississippi regiment.
We stayed there for, oh, two months, I guess.
We paraded every afternoon.
These infantrymen were the people from Jackson who'd come out there and see us parade.
We'd pass and review, pass and review, pass and review, march and march and march.
When we weren't...
standing still, we were marching and when we weren't moving, if there was a train on the track, we just marched in place.
We just marched.
And we're pretty good paraders now, but we didn't know a three, we'd never seen a 75 and there wasn't but one three-inch battery, the old Washington artillery of the world, of
Confederacy was the only battery we had and it just shot all over the lot.
It was loose.
One, one, one battery for a whole brigade now.
For about a month or two.
And then, and then they sent the majors on out there and they busted all of them.
Then they sent a capital two and none of them came back.
I mean for the whole brigade now.
Well, I don't know.
I don't think I volunteered, but I guess I did too much talking.
And so they sent me.
And by golly, I thought I was going to bust out short because it was tough.
It was fast.
Every Saturday we had about four or five examinations, 30 minutes.
You had to pass it off.
You had to answer a whole lot and write and it had to be fast.
Well, I'm sure I didn't do too darn well because every single Sunday morning for about six weeks I always went down to look at the casualty list.
They published the casualty list.
Those that failed,
on the exams the previous Saturday morning.
That was published Sunday morning with orders to proceed back to your outfit.
Well, when you got back to your outfit, you were b-boarded, which meant give up your commission.
And I'd have been drafted.
And I, oh Lord, I was, I'd say under pressure.
I didn't think I was any better than some of the others that were flunking.
But thank goodness I made it.
After ten weeks I knew I had it made.
After six weeks of the ten I knew I had it made.
Well I got back to the brigade, the first one from the three regiments that passed that school of fire.
And the old general over there, he didn't know any more about artillery than anybody else because he's
real old timer and artillery was getting to be a little more technical.
You had to know some trigonometry and had to be able to figure out how you could hit something over there and you're over here and you're looking over yonder.
And well,
I got back and was the first one.
And this old general, he was an old boy, didn't know modern stuff.
He said, I just don't know anything about that damn school, but I know it's just running my outfit.
And I want you to start a school.
And I was his school officer for the balance of the war.
And we had a school there and I tried to teach them as much as I could in the time.

But then after I'd been on that a few weeks, he got orders to send a group of people over to France, the head of the division, the head of the brigade, to go to this French school to learn about the French 75 and the 155.
And I had a first sergeant from every battery, three regiments now, Mississippi, Arkansas, Louisiana.
I had a first sergeant from every outfit.
I had a second lieutenant from every outfit.
And he was supposed to be a bright young man that had maybe been through the French school over at, what you call it,
and then it'd come back.
And so I had all that bunch of people.
We went overseas and I remember when we landed at Lahore we could hear the front, the big guns.
That's as near as I ever got to firing or receiving any fire in anger.
So
I took this bunch of young officers to this school, Equiquidon, that's in Brittany.
French school, artillery school.
We went through that artillery school and when our regiments came over there, these officers, there were two to every batterer plus me.
And so we were ready then to teach our people stuff.
Then we went and fired and then we went firing and we went.
We had 70 rounds in our battalion at 11 o'clock on November 11th.
Armistice Day when we got the word the truce was signed.
And I gave one command.
It was a standing barrage that we shot 70 rounds.
That's the way we celebrated the armistice.
We were just finishing that morning, that day.
At 11 o'clock, we shot those 500 rounds.
And then there we were.
There's the war over, and we finished the day on our train.
Well, what are they going to do now?
Can't send everybody, two million people back home the same day.
And so they give, I don't know what happened to the other three regiments.
I don't know what happened to the regiment from Louisiana or the regiment from Arkansas.
But the regiment from Mississippi was sent to Valdehan, Valdon, the way they pronounce it, up near the Swiss border, where there was a specialized French school.
on artillery and I mean the arranges and things like that for it.

We were sent over there and the old general always had me for his, he always made me on every dog gun, I was summer court martial and a member of a special court and one time I was on a general court martial
at different places.
But we stayed at Valadol until we got home in July of the next summer.
firing for that school.
Because they kept an army of occupation.
They wanted to offer me a job.
I was a major, but I'd have to go back as a captain in the regular army.
But I didn't think I wanted to be in the army in peacetime.
And I wasn't in the army in peacetime until the Second World War came along.
And I didn't have to go then.
But they asked me,
to report to Fort Sill on August the 4th, ever when it was, and I did.
And I got up there and went through the basic course, and I went through the field officer's course.
There were seven of us.
Probably, they called us the Eagle Squadron, because we had a bird on our shoulders, you see.
They don't know what to do with us, because we're too old to go over.
Or if we weren't, we would be in a few months.
I got to be, I was too old to go over, because I was already 52.
And you couldn't go over unless you were a general officer.
They'd take you more than over 52, but that was the cutoff age.
And those people, those people, I was just more or less in their way.
And we stayed up there though for a good many weeks at Fort Sill, heading boards, investigation boards, and that was all right.
And then we were on the board that would approve an enlisted man who wanted to go to officer's training camp, and that was all right.
And one time, a boy whose daddy was,
the engineer prof here, and I was at this time, he was in school now, I'm back down yonder in the athletic field.
No, that's what I was a commandant.
No, I guess I'd given up the commandant's job.
But at least I'm the oldest of this colonel bunch.
And as a result, I'm the chairman of this little thing.
this little committee.
And here comes a boy into that thing and when he saw me his eyes popped.
He was a member of my golf team at A&M College.
Just before I left here, my other stuff out there, I was just coaching the golf team for the fun of it.
And they taught me a lot of golf.
I didn't know any golf.
But at least I took them on trips and everything like that.
And old Foraker,
He's been offered the presidency of this school a number of times and turns it down.
He's a big man up at Harvard right now.
He walked into that thing, because I recognized him and he recognized me.
And I said, oh boy, I'm glad to see you.
But you don't have to worry.
Because you got it made.
You just go back and tell them that we're going to give you a favorable report.
I didn't even talk to these other officers that are on this committee.
And then I'd explain to them just who this boy is and what I know about him and what I know about his daddy.
And just a fine engineer.
And he's up at Harvard.
He's had a chance to come here as president.
That was a fun little story.
I was wondering about the changes in the Southwest Conference.
How's that?
The changes in the Southwest Conference.
Have there been major changes in the Southwest Conference, do you think?
I think the Southwest Conference,
Of course, the coaching profession has progressed a long, long way.
Yeah, could you talk about that?
And it progressed when the ex-bible came here.
We had an old man by the name of Charlie Moran, famous, famous old boy.
He coached Center College to a national championship.
You ever heard about that?
No.
Well, they beat Harvard and Harvard was the best team in the east and the center beat them and everybody else that played.
They went out and beat a composite team out on the west coast at a Christmas game after winning everything over here.
Then they made a mistake of coming back to Dallas and playing Texas A&M on New Year's Day and we beat them.
and that then gave us the claim to national championship because that's what they were and we beat them.
Now, D. X. Bible was the new school.
The man that went to
Wallace Wade was the man that was at that little Tennessee prep school in the Desjardins County.
Wallace Wade.
He coached at Alabama when our present coach was there.
He played for Wallace Wade.
And Wallace Wade went from there to Vanderbilt, and then he went to Duke where he stayed, I guess, until he quit.
He and Bob were the two young coaches that were together in those adjoining counties in Tennessee.
Tennessee in those days had very few high schools, but they had some fine prep schools that had just run by a man who had a staff and a building, and he had a prep school.
So those were two prep schools.
Brandon at Shelbyville, Tennessee, and the other over at Tallahoma.
Now, what did, now... You were talking about the changes in the Southwest Conference.
The change was that people started to recruiting.
I see.
We took boys that came here.
D. X. Bobble and I, we'd never had an automobile in 1922, the spring of 22.
We stayed here until the final parade.
And then we got onto a little old car that we bought for $600 and headed for the west coast.
We were both Shriners and they were having the Shrine Convention in San Francisco and so we decided to go to it.
We'd never been anywhere, we never had a car or anything like that, but we started out and we made it in seven days.
And then we went up the coast.
Went to the convention after we had already gone down to Mexico and on up the coast to San Francisco.
Then we came back through Patajo and Winnemucca and that's in Nevada and then Salt Lake and then we came around through Colorado and came on home.
Stayed here about three days.
three or four days just to kind of see how things were coming along.
Then we head out for Tennessee.
He lives a little above Knoxville and I live on the other side of Knoxville.
We got to Nashville and there's a railroad that went from there straight to Knoxville, Tennessee Central.
It doesn't run now, but it did then.
He caught the train home.
I gave him $250 for his part of the car.
Drove it in.
We had seven fairs between, I had seven fairs between here and Sparta, Tennessee.
Six of them.
Didn't have many roads, but we didn't stay here and recruit.
We came here just to be here in time school started.
I never did get here until maybe two days before school started every year.
Never thought we were trying to recruit anybody.
But these other teams got ahead of us while we were coasting along.
And D-X was doing just better than anybody under the old deal.
But the track wasn't doing too much.
Baseball and basketball and everything like that didn't matter, don't matter now to a lot of people.
Football had just got so big.
But they're going to build us a new stadium.
That is, they'll put up some steel bleachers or something and move the track right west of the baseball field.
You know where I'm talking about now.
I read in the paper yesterday about where they're going to build three new intramural fields over there and the track.
I have another question.
During the 1960s, after you retired, A&M of course let women in and they also stopped the mandatory corps.
So people did not have to join the corps of cadets.
I was wondering what you thought of those changes.
I love the corps.
I love that uniform.
I've put more in that uniform than many people.
I've had two wars in it.
I love this corps.
But I didn't like the initiation of this perpetual four-year fraternity life that was driving the other people off and choking the school to death, and nobody's doing anything about it.
I'm the individual that challenged this thing and started this ball rolling.
And Gib Gilchrist, my very close friend, was here when I was doing it, and he wanted to do what I...
was doing.
He was a Texas University man and I don't believe that there ever been an A&M man to do what I did or what he did.
Somebody had to come in here from somebody else.
And not a silly thing, chasing them off with bore every Friday night once a year, was not a silly thing.
to do the things they do to carol from Ann's Barn or take anybody's woodpile or just do anything they wanted to do.
Wasn't it a silly thing to make freshmen wait on you?
Here's another thing they did.
Dean Bolton was a very conservative man.
He was in charge of the Blue Book.
The Blue Book was the rules that the faculty and the board of directors had adopted
to take care of discipline and other things in this college.
I went to, I guess after the first term in that chair, I went to Bing Bolton and I said, Bing Bolton, there's not any use in them keeping those freshmen
in a cage, they make them stay right there in the dormitory.
They're in the last class.
They can't go to Brown.
They can't do anything.
They have to stay there so they can wait on the upperclassmen.
I said, now listen, Dean, let's you and I change that thing.
After a man has passed his December the 10th testing age, and he's passing all of his work, Dean Bolton,
Let's make those people give those boys a little bit of privilege.
Oh, Mr. Edison, let's just let it alone.
Let's just let it alone.
All right, we let it alone.
Next fall, I didn't ask Dean Bolton anything.
I just got out an order.
From now on out, when that freshman's last class is over with, he's a free man to call to quarters.
He can go to town if he wants to.
That's revolutionary.
Nobody says I can't do it.
The student body doesn't like it at all.
But there wasn't anybody there with enough guts to say you can't do that.
I forced stuff on this college.
I've never told anybody that.
But I did force that on the senior class.
You cannot keep this boy in quarters just to be there to run your errands and do your stuff.
He's a free man if he's passing his grades on December the 10th.
I was a reasonable person.
I cooperated when I was sensible to cooperate and tried to get a job done that I felt like should be done by somebody.
Oh, maybe.
And they weren't too hard to handle.
They gave that paddle up, just about gave that paddle up.
I don't say that they didn't do it after I left.
I don't know.
I know that they'd better not do too much of it because Gilchrist wouldn't fool with them.
He just accepted their resignation and said, we can get along without you.
And they hadn't done anything to do but swallow it.
I accept your resignation, but you can take the job back if you want it.
But by golly, I ain't on my terms.
That's what he said.
That's what he did.
And then they, but they forced us to go further than that.
They forced us to go to the state.
I went over there with him.
And the committee from both houses there asked us questions.
and they told the people over here what was what.
Of course, the darn Korean War just about ruined military in this country.
Well, it was a damn full war.
They shouldn't have never gone over there.

I used to write Teague every so often and plead with him, Teague, stand on your feet and tell these people over there that they should have never landed a single man on the continent of Asia with a rifle in his hand.
If you want to fight those boys, you've got to be mean enough to blow them off the face of the earth and have it over with.
If you don't want to do that, then
I couldn't get him to do that either.
But we made a terrible mistake going over there.
You can't fight, they're a bunch of red ants.
You kill 10 to our one, pretty soon we run out of people.
And besides, they fought in the bushes.
They never did get out and fight like an army.
We made a horrible mistake and just ruined their military
As far as popularity with the people concerned, they just, everybody had to be against that war.
Except the people that got it started and couldn't quit.
Until they finally did.
Oh, we're just talking about a lot of the stuff that I have lived through.
Had a good time, fine place, wouldn't change it for anything in the world.
Good wife, good boys, wonderful boys, two fine sons.
Both of them, Rusty and my doctor son lives right over there.
He lives in Brown, we live in College Station.
Right there are those trees that I built up and planted some time ago.
there between us, that's all.
He was in Arabia last, came back ten days ago.
They had him come over there for thirty days.
He's an eye specialist.
And transplant some corneas and take out some lumps out of the eye, what is it, when you have cataracts, yeah.
Well he did that for thirty days.
just to see what it's like.
They paid him well.
He's just back from it.
He came back walking home with one of those dirt long robes over and a thing over his head and a little ring around the top the other day.
And the other boy, the other boy stayed here for a couple of years and then he went to Annapolis.
And he was the top man up there.
He was the brigade captain his senior year and that same cadet colonel here.
So I'm very proud of him.
He didn't stay in the Air Force or the Navy.
I heard he stayed in there eight years, and then he decided his wife didn't like the service.
He liked it all right, but his wife didn't, so he decided just go into business.
He's with the Southland Corporation up in Dallas.
He does a good job.
We had both of them and their families in there for food yesterday, Saturday, Sunday at noon.
get them together and we got two fine sons.
We sure like them.
Sure like them.
Sure proud of them.
What do you think of the future of Texas A&M?
What do you think of the future of Texas A&M?
But listen, there's one other thing I want to say.
There's a picture of the man that decided that they needed a marker down there on the track.
old Pat Olson, Helen standing right there by him.
She was the mother and sponsor of that track team all during the years.
I don't think I'd ever got too far without her because she just, she just was just nice to those kids and they liked her.
She'd feed them when the year was over and she'd be with them on the bus wherever they'd go, here, there, and yonder.
and she's just a great gal.
But the, I guess I'm a little bit unique in the fact that I just never did leave the place, and in athletics.
Never did, never was fired except
I quit.
For a few hours.
And there was fire, never did quit.
That's pretty good for a coach.
No kidding.
That's an accomplishment in itself.
Well thanks a lot for this interview.
We'll have it typed up for you.
